items.title: Raid on Georgia E.V. Battery Plant Raises New Risks for a Shaken Industry
items.summary: Foreign manufacturers were already dealing with tariffs and the end of E.V. tax credits. Now, they face greater scrutiny of their workers’ immigration status.

items.title: Trial to Begin for Ryan Routh, Man Charged in Trump Assassination Attempt in Florida
items.summary: Ryan Routh has pleaded not guilty and plans to defend himself in court. The most serious charge against him carries a sentence of up to life in prison.

items.title: How Local Jails Are Helping ICE Detentions
items.summary: As ICE detains more immigrants and detention centers exceed capacity, the agency is turning to local jails. Allison McCann, a reporter and graphics editor for The New York Times, visited one jail holding detainees in Ohio.

items.title: Miami Has a Padel ‘Obsession’
items.summary: Residents who love fitness and socializing — and can afford to play — cannot get enough of padel, the racket sport with international cachet.

items.title: West Point Alumni Group Cancels Award Honoring Tom Hanks
items.summary: The group was to bestow the Sylvanus Thayer Award on the actor, but it said it was canceling the event to focus on preparing academy cadets for the future.

items.title: John Burton, 92, Dies; California Political Boss Who Staged a Comeback
items.summary: He left the House of Representatives while struggling with a crack addiction, his political career seemingly over. Actually, it had just begun.

items.title: Trump tells foreign firms to ‘respect’ immigration laws after Hyundai raid – US politics live
items.summary: <p>President says he welcomes investments by overseas companies but adds they should ‘hire and train American workers’</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/07/300-south-koreans-detained-at-hyundai-plant-in-us-to-be-released-says-seoul">300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US ‘to be released’</a></p></li></ul><p>Intent on vindication after spending four months in prison last year, <strong>Peter Navarro</strong> asked a federal appeals court on Sunday night to force <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump’s</a> justice department to explain why it would not defend his 2022 conviction for defying a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-capitol-breach">January 6</a> committee subpoena.</p><p>The request to the US court of appeals for the DC circuit is fraught for the department as it would have to confront the appearance that it <a href="https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.cadc.40540/gov.uscourts.cadc.40540.2132720.0.pdf">quietly dropped the case</a> in order to shield Navarro after he was tapped as a senior adviser to the president.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/sep/08/donald-trump-immigration-hyundai-tariffs-us-politics-live-news-updates">Continue reading...</a>

items.title: Critics say BlackRock’s Minnesota utility bid will increase rates – and clean energy goals will suffer
items.summary: <p>Sale opponents say private equity’s profit-seeking is at odds with reasonable rates and state’s goal to decarbonize</p><p>A bid by financial giant BlackRock to acquire a Minnesota electric utility could push up <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/19/electricity-bills-increase-trump">already-soaring</a> utility bills, opponents warn.</p><p>The private equity firm Global Infrastructure Partners, a division of BlackRock, <a href="https://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/local/duluth-based-allete-agrees-to-6-8-billion-investment-partnership">announced a $6.2bn deal last year</a> to take over the parent company of a Duluth-based electric utility which serves more than 150,000 customers, if the state’s public utilities commission gives the green light.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/08/blackrock-minnesota-power-sale-allete">Continue reading...</a>
